newsitem.title: SPAIN: NATO invites Hungary, Poland, Czechs to join.
newsitem.headline: NATO invites Hungary, Poland, Czechs to join.

text.p: NATO on Tuesday formally invited Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic to join, in the biggest single expansion of the Western alliance in its 48-year history.
An announcement read by Secretary-General Javier Solana during a summit of the 16-member alliance in Madrid also named Slovenia and Romania as prime candidates for the next round of expansion.

The official declaration also gave favourable mention to the Baltic states as "aspiring members" without specifically naming the former Soviet republics of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia. Russia has warned that it would consider NATO membership by the Baltics as a threat to its own security.

"Today the heads of state and government have agreed to invite the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland to begin accession talks with NATO," Solana told the assembled alliance leaders and the news media.

"Our goal is to sign the protocol of accession ... in December 1997 and to see the ratification process completed in time for membership to become effective for the 50th anniversary (of NATO's creation in April 1999)."

Solana, speaking after hours of wrangling between delegations over the exact wording of the expansion declaration, said NATO remains "open to new members" and expects to extend further invitations in coming years.
